Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Surface Plasmon Resonance in the Mid-infrared
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program, Profs. Stefan Franzen and Jon-Paul Maria of North Carolina State University and Karl Booksh of the University of Delaware are investigating the structure/property relationships that regulate surface chemical interactions, and the mid-infrared optical properties of electrically conducting oxides, metallic nanoparticles, and their hybrid combinations. Specifically, the multidisciplinary team is studying surface plasmon oscillations in the mid-infrared, and how those oscillations can be tuned by modulating the nanostructure of conducting oxides. Effects on tunability of these optical phenomena by incorporation of metallic nanoparticles are also under investigation.

The work seeks new understanding of how light interacts with solid surfaces. It will provide new opportunities to probe the attachment of macromolecules and biomolecules on robust oxide surfaces, enabling novel mechanisms for surface characterization and sensing. It also provides opportunities for graduate students (particularly those from underrepresented groups) to collaborate with researchers in Poland and China through the PIs' well-established international exchange programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to investigate the utility of performing surface plasmon resonance (SPR) spectroscopy in the infrared region of the electromagnetic spectrum. Analytical SPR measurements are commonly performed on planar gold surfaces. Moving from the visible to the infrared spectral region increases the bulk sensitivity of the measurement while increasing the penetration depth of the surface plasmon; this can result in a net gain or net loss of surface sensitivity to target analytes bound to surface receptors. We are, additionally, looking at ordered nanohole arrays that are plasmonically active in the infrared. Nanohole arrays supportmultiple surface plasmons that can be tailored by changing the size and spacing of the holes in the arrays.

One outcome was the development of an instrumental component capable of collecting SPR spectra in the infrared region. This component was designed to fit into a commercially available FT-IR instrument. Patents are pending and a company is looking to manufacture the instrumentation.

One goal was optimizing ordered nanohole arrays for maximizing analytical surface sensitivity. Approaching this goal required improving methodology for accurately determining the penetration depth of surface plasmons. SPR measurements are dependent on the optical properties of the plasmonic material and the optical properties of the sample to be analyzed. It is assumed that the optical properties of the plasmonic material is constant. However, binding an adlayer, to determine penetration depth, changes the optical properties of the plasmonic gold structures. The accepted method failed to account for this effect. Consequently, the determined penetration depth could be off my more that 100% or even negative.  We expanded the model to incorporate multiple adlayers for determining the effect of binding an adayer to the plasmonic structure. The result was more reliable estimation of plasmonic properties needed to optimize sensor design.

We studied to interaction between ordered nanohole arrays and single nanoparticles. We modified a hybrid atomic force – Raman microscope to controllably ‘image’ an ordered nanohole array with a single gold nanoparticle. We tracked the plasmonic intensity and wavelength as a position on relative location to the nanohole array. This information is being employed to optimize signal amplification for plasmonic sensors.

We investigated plasmonic polymers as a sensing surface. Theory shows that some conducting polymers, such as polyaniline and polyacetylene should support surface plasmons; however SPR has never been directly observed. Modeling indicated that we needed to deposit a 50 nm thick film with less than 2 nm RMS roughness to observe a SP in the infrared region.  We published papers on making thin polyaniline films and employing the films as a chemical sensor, but did not observe a SPR spectrum. An interesting outcome was the construction of an infrared surface plasmon waveguide (SPWG) using the polyaniline. The IR SPWG has potential for identification and quantification of dissolved oils in water.

The project had a significant ‘broadening participation’ component. We brought in 3 undergraduate students with disabilities to participate in the research project. Students with disabilities are severely underrepresented in STEM at all levels.
